G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and this is a civil action at law for personal injury.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8 because the cause of action arose in Worcester County and the Property where the incident occurred is located at 123 Maple Street, Worcester, MA 01603.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner or person in control of real property owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to the condition of the property and conduct of third persons, including the duty to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors against unreasonable risks of harm.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors regarding conditions on the land. Although the provided excerpt is only Kaplan’s concurrence and focuses on concerns about the treatment of trespassers, the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707 explicitly adopts a unitary ‘reasonable care’ standard for all lawful entrants, which matches the proposition about the landowner’s duty to maintain reasonably safe premises and protect against unreasonable risks of harm. The concurrence does not contradict that core holding.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707, not shown in the excerpt provided:] "We therefore hold that the duty owed by an occupier of land in Massachusetts to all lawful visitors is the duty of reasonable care under all of the circumstances. The occupier must act as a reasonable person in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition and in taking those precautions that are reasonably necessary to protect lawful visitors from foreseeable risks of harm."

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an owner or person in control of premises has a duty to remedy or warn of known or reasonably knowable hazards, including snow and ice conditions, within a reasonable time after they arise.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and holds that snow and ice hazards are governed by the same reasonable-care standard as other premises hazards. It explains that a property owner who knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous snow or ice condition must take reasonable steps to protect lawful visitors, which includes remedying the condition or otherwise making the property reasonably safe within a reasonable time under the circumstances. This directly aligns with the proposition stated.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: The duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to act as a reasonably prudent property owner would under similar circumstances, taking into account foreseeable weather conditions, melt and refreeze cycles, frequency of use, and the foreseeability of harm to lawful visitors.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The case discusses a landowner’s common-law duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors but in a very general way; it does not elaborate that this duty specifically includes considering weather conditions, melt/refreeze cycles, frequency of use, or similar factors. Instead, it addresses whether a racetrack owner had any duty to alter or seek alterations to an adjacent state highway (e.g., traffic lights or pedestrian bridges) and concludes no such duty exists. The detailed, weather- and condition-based formulation in the proposition is not drawn from this opinion’s holding or reasoning.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

*Humphrey v. Byron*, 447 Mass. 322, 329\.proposition: Defendant’s duty extended to maintaining the sidewalk and principal walking paths in a condition that would be reasonably safe for foreseeable users, or to provide adequate warning and alternative safe routes if a particular area could not reasonably be maintained safely.
*Humphrey v. Byron*, 447 Mass. 322, 329\.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a commercial landlord’s duty for unsafe stairs inside a leased building and expressly declines to expand landlord duties beyond common law rules. It reaffirms that a commercial lessor is only liable if it contracted to repair or retained control over a common or appurtenant area, and does not discuss a duty to maintain sidewalks or principal walking paths, nor to provide warnings or alternative safe routes. Thus, it does not establish or support the broader duty described in the proposition.
*Humphrey v. Byron*, 447 Mass. 322, 329\.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today leaves intact the rule that ‘a lessor of commercial premises is liable in tort for personal injuries only if either (1) he contracted to make repairs and made them negligently, or (2) the defect that caused the injury was in a “common area,” or other area appurtenant to the leased area, over which the lessor had some control.’… Gateway leased the entire building from the landlord, including the stairway where Humphrey’s accident occurred. It was Gateway’s responsibility to keep the leased premises safe….”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Defendant’s duty extended to maintaining the sidewalk and principal walking paths in a condition that would be reasonably safe for foreseeable users, or to provide adequate warning and alternative safe routes if a particular area could not reasonably be maintained safely.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The case deals with a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger created by placing a trampoline next to a shallow pool; it does not concern sidewalks, principal walking paths, or providing alternative safe routes. The holding is that a landowner may have a duty to remedy an open and obvious condition on the premises when the owner can and should anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter it despite the risk. The proposition about maintaining sidewalks and principal walking paths and providing alternative routes is not drawn from this opinion’s facts or reasoning and misstates its scope.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances…’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg… We consider the scope of a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger….”}

*Papadopoulos*, 457 Mass. at 378\u201379.proposition: Massachusetts law requires property owners to act reasonably in responding to winter conditions; they may not simply do nothing or unreasonably delay in treating snow and ice hazards.
